The Consumer Rights Act 2015 will make it far easier for groups of consumers to seek compensation from firms that have fixed prices and formed cartels. It introduces "collective redress" and "mandatory mediation" – two ways of settling disputes that would have taken years of litigation by individuals to achieve.

Collective redress is when companies have engaged in collusion, which, if it cannot be remedied voluntarily, falls within the scope of the Act. Consumers – who, if they feel wronged, should be able to group together to pursue firms that collude with one another – will be able to take on large, organised firms through collective redress; with the exception of the Post Office and railway operators, the only other large businesses covered.

Three officers were shot dead by an eastern European gang in a bungled east London burglary in December 1910. The murders led to the famous Siege of Sidney Street, the first attempt at an English-style, or 'Czar' trial, but ended instead with the execution of the gang leader and six of his associates. Despite being'sensational' and 'a national sensation', the case and its aftermath led to little more than a minor stir in the press and the public. As historian Paul Beales shows us, the Sidney Street affair was typical of British crime reporting in that it dealt with the issue of crime rather than its causes, perpetuated the 'dangerous immigrants' stereotype of the time – albeit here those immigrants came from the East – and sought to re-establish the moral foundations of the state following years of political and social change.

London: Sidney Street Gang: A Story of Crime Journalism on Trial, Paul Beales
